title: If our decisions affect our future, then theoretically if we knew our future or as some people call it “fate” then how would that affect our decision making? - Quora

response.answer_text: Of course our decisions often affect our future — our fate, if you choose to look at it that way. But we cannot know our future for sure, because it is, or at least might be, affected by factors beyond our control. Still, we must make decisions, and we do so in the present based on our judgment of our capabilities, talents, and potential, along with our understanding of where are now, where we want to go, and what we might want to do when we get there. All subject to change with little or no warning. I know I didn’t exactly answer the question, but I couldn’t, as it is based on a false premise.

It makes no sense to “decide” something that is fated, i.e. determined to happen come what may. So knowing our own future (in detail) is incompatible with choosing now: either our future is determined by ourselves or by something else. Of course we generally don’t know our future; that’s why we choose and decide. But it doesn’t follow that our future is dependent on our choice. The only point is that we can’t both know our future and choose it.

If it is foreordained that things will happen a certain way, then we will also find ways to make those decisions the same way whether we know our future or not. Freedom in decision making and an immutable future are mutually exclusive concepts.

It would improve our act. Our decisions are made in the mind (the guide) and the body follows thru (a missile). It is better if we “call the shots,” rather than always depend upon randomness and arbitrariness, although both can work complimentary.
You can never know your future by whatever act you do or tools you use. Life is dynamic and in the process of movement decision making is involved. Outcome is an entirely different event.
you make your future your future does not make you
